posts.name: Çağan
posts.cooked:
A system has come to my mind aimed at minimizing driver errors. The robot will always know its location during the match. When the teleopa passes, I will press the L4 key, go to throw it, press another button to purchase coral, and return to the station.

To summarize, the logic involves using inputs like button presses to guide the robot. For instance, the robot can defend by applying consistent force or navigate obstacles by adjusting its path.

However, fully autonomous navigation presents challenges. The robot may need to climb barriers or avoid teammates' interference. To address this, additional controls—like a keypad or computer—are planned alongside the existing PS5 controller for precise command execution.

I aim to employ the principles used in robot vacuum cleaners, requiring numerous sensors for this task. Is this feasible? Are there teams capable of achieving this?

Note: This response excludes the translator's note due to the instruction to omit unnecessary elements.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: This level of automation is absolutely feasible. Teams employ advanced pathfinding to automatically score coral, enabling them to monitor where they need to accumulate ranking points. The robot then decides where to place the pieces, eliminating human delays. I’d examine team 6328 for examples, since they excel in automation and share their resources effectively.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
The text is: 

"There are teams that have tried working on approaches for this, but it has yet to be completely worth it for a team to use in a match. The issue is that humans can think two steps ahead and plan routes around things a robot just couldn’t reasonably predict. Also, the vantage point from the driver station tends to be better for getting a full scope and sense of a match compared to a robot-mounted sensor/camera."

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Teams like 254 utilize adaptive pathing algorithms to navigate around obstacles such as defense by altering course instead of continuing on the current route. While this method isn’t always optimal, it frequently proves effective. When there are no other robots obstructing the path—a common occurrence despite this—it typically results in faster automatic navigation compared to human-driven operations, reducing issues related to joystick control and limited visibility, especially in challenging environments like the reef.

Strategic planning in matches can be achieved by defining "coral priorities," which determine the robot’s focus areas during navigation. This allows a human operator to guide the robot to previously scored sections of the reef, enhancing efficiency. Currently, fully autonomous algae systems aren’t available, but advancements in automation suggest they could become feasible in the future.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Fully automated algae systems haven’t been widely implemented yet, but using similar technologies from other applications could potentially achieve this. However, I’ve observed numerous successful implementations during Einstein matches, highlighting their effectiveness.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked: Dave Powers said he couldn't do it, so I can't either.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: Yup, definitely. Our team had it as well… Probably should’ve known that.

posts.name: David Powers
posts.cooked: @jonahb55 and @SuryaT can speak to the automation we use a lot better than I can. I just know we drive to open part of the reef, push a button, and the robot scores based on what we've set the priority to be, basically magic to me, really.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: We did exactly this year, and our code is available here.

link_counts.title: GitHub - fairviewrobotics/2025-robot-code: The code for the Black Knights Robotics 2025 Reefscape robot

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
We have a substantial foundation that could enable autonomous navigation around obstacles in theory. We can reliably track the robot's pose, reef state, and most game pieces on the floor. In both 2023 and 2025, we used this data to automate a significant portion of the game, including complex sequencing/field navigation for scoring, automatic strategy to optimize game piece placements, and auto alignment/sequencing for intake. At some of our events this year, the robot was fully autonomous for over 50% of the match time (and partially autonomous for an even longer duration). With some relatively minor additions, such as extra cameras and retrained models, we could, in principle, track other robots too. At that point, there’s no compelling reason why we couldn’t develop ways to automate the rest of the match in a similar fashion.

However, just because we can doesn’t mean we should. Full automation of the robot has never been our objective; we see automation as a tool that enhances human drivers' capabilities in areas where they excel. Managing the robots’ moment-to-moment movement around the field remains challenging for software since it pertains to the overall gameplay of the alliance rather than individual robots. Our aim is to liberate the driver from low-level optimizations, allowing them to focus on higher-level tasks and reduce practice time and focus on less critical details. Essentially, our goal is to use automation to improve the driver’s performance and ensure they remain productive.
